佢個傷難搞係難搞
但未至於咁賤

參考下

As I wrote in May, there was not much of a market for him -- and almost none among teams with cap space once Dallas and DeAndre Jordan pulled the NBA version of college crushes who finally (and sloppily) make the leap when they run into each other at a bar in their mid-20s.

A number of teams had a No Cousins policy before he tore his Achilles. That number grew as teams feared committing to what might be a less explosive version of him.

By the middle of Monday, Cousins' people were calling teams and pitching deals: one-year, $15 million in one place, per sources, other numbers in other places. Clearly, there was not much interest. It may be that the richest deal easily and quickly available to him was that full midlevel exception contract starting at around $8.6 million.

Any team offering that -- and I'm not sure as of this writing that one did -- might have sensed its leverage, and tried to coax Cousins into a two-year deal at that price. For many of them, that was the smart play. Cousins would have justifiably resisted.

Cousins told Marc Spears of The Undefeated that he had no offers as of Monday morning, and instructed his agent to start calling teams -- including the Warriors.

The Dallas Mavericks, the team with cap space most motivated to sign a center, quickly agreed to terms with DeAndre Jordan. The Los Angeles Lakers evidently prioritized perimeter players for the one-year contracts they were offering, signing former Golden State center JaVale McGee for the veteran's minimum. And Cousins' former team, the New Orleans Pelicans, got a cheaper, younger replacement in Julius Randle after the Lakers renounced his rights.

With the remaining teams with cap space either rebuilding (Atlanta and Chicago), in no need of a center (Philadelphia) or uninterested in a reunion (Sacramento), those moves left a sign-and-trade deal as Cousins' only real hope of getting more than the $8.6 million non-taxpayer midlevel exception.

Unless there's a suitor we don't know about, odds are Cousins actually didn't sacrifice much money to take the Warriors' smaller taxpayer midlevel. At that point, the chance to join the defending champs was probably worth taking slightly less money for one year. Cousins will return to free agency in a year hoping for a better market, as more teams will have cap space and he'll be a year further removed from the ruptured Achilles tendon that ended his 2017-18 season before the All-Star break.

http://www.espn.com/nba/story/_/id/23980154/how-much-better-does-demarcus-cousins-make-golden-state-warriors-nba

With the remaining teams with cap space either rebuilding (Atlanta and Chicago), in no need of a center (Philadelphia) or uninterested in a reunion (Sacramento), those moves left a sign-and-trade deal as Cousins' only real hope of getting more than the $8.6 million non-taxpayer midlevel exception.

Unless there's a suitor we don't know about, odds are Cousins actually didn't sacrifice much money to take the Warriors' smaller taxpayer midlevel. At that point, the chance to join the defending champs was probably worth taking slightly less money for one year. Cousins will return to free agency in a year hoping for a better market, as more teams will have cap space and he'll be a year further removed from the ruptured Achilles tendon that ended his 2017-18 season before the All-Star break.

A number of teams had a No Cousins policy before he tore his Achilles. That number grew as teams feared committing to what might be a less explosive version of him.

By the middle of Monday, Cousins' people were calling teams and pitching deals: one-year, $15 million in one place, per sources, other numbers in other places. Clearly, there was not much interest

Any team offering that -- and I'm not sure as of this writing that one did -- might have sensed its leverage, and tried to coax Cousins into a two-year deal at that price. For many of them, that was the smart play. Cousins would have justifiably resisted.

A one-year deal didn't make much sense for almost any other team beyond Golden State. Due to his injury, you are getting only part of that season. You may not get another; there are strict salary limits in re-signing players who change teams on one-year deals.

在一月份的跟腱撕裂過後，Cousins就在擔心傷病是否會影響他的自由球員市場。答案就是：會影響。Cousins說他自己沒有收到任何一份報價。這讓他特別沮喪。週一凌晨5點的時候他站在拉斯維基斯的住處的陽台上想著自己的未來應該怎麼辦，他電話把他的經紀人叫醒，二人討論了很多種可能性，其中一種就是去勇士。

所以早上他打電話給總經理Bob Myers，二人進行了交流，Bob表示自己很驚訝，Cousins居然給他打了電話。

A number of teams had a No Cousins policy before he tore his Achilles. That number grew as teams feared committing to what might be a less explosive version of him.

By the middle of Monday, Cousins' people were calling teams and pitching deals: one-year, $15 million in one place, per sources, other numbers in other places. Clearly, there was not much interest

Any team offering that -- and I'm not sure as of this writing that one did -- might have sensed its leverage, and tried to coax Cousins into a two-year deal at that price. For many of them, that was the smart play. Cousins would have justifiably resisted.

A one-year deal didn't make much sense for almost any other team beyond Golden State. Due to his injury, you are getting only part of that season. You may not get another; there are strict salary limits in re-signing players who change teams on one-year deals.

根據「三立新聞網」報導，三立「綜藝玩很大」傳出將邀請有「大鬍子」之稱的NBA年度 MVP哈登（James Harden）。 這也將是「玩很大」開播以來最重量級的節目來賓。製作人湯宗霖對此說：「目前正在溝 通當中，趁他來台灣，所以邀他來上節目。」 湯宗霖也表示會再發出採訪邀請，到時狀況會更明朗。 剛拿下年度MVP的火箭球星哈登預計將在7月4日、5日來台，這也是他繼2013年後再度造訪 寶島，而這次點頭答應錄「玩很大」，這也將是他首次登上台灣綜藝節目，讓不少粉絲都 相當期待。
